notes: On 20 February 2018, protesters gathered for a demonstration in Krasnodar against a local building development. The protest was organized by shareholders of the building project who felt defrauded by the project and local residents who were displaced by the construction.
On 20 February 2020, about 20 people took part in an authorized protest in Barnaul against the plans to construct a new Altai State University building in the place of a local park.
On 15 March 2020, over 50 people took part in an authorized protest in Syktyvkar against the creation of new waste-collection plants in the region.
On 20 January 2020, 8 activists took part in a series of coordinated one-person protests in Makhachkala in support of a local activist and journalist who is accused of financing terror groups.
On 17 January 2021, about 60 people staged an unauthorized protest in Severodvinsk against the construction of a new apartment complex in the zone that was initially meant for a park.
On the 20 October 2018, people gathered in Pomorye to protest against the construction of a landfill and environmental technology park.

source: Echo Moscow; Argumenty I Fakty; Media Korset
notes: On 29 February 2020, about 800 people took part in an authorized protest in Ufa against the heating fee hikes.
On 14 December 2019, about 60 people took part in an authorized protest in Mirny against the plans to construct a new toxic waste recycling plant in the region.

On 4 November 2018, between 20 and 30 protesters took part in a nationalist anti-government march in the city of Novosibirsk coinciding with the National Unity Day holiday. No injuries or arrests were reported.
On 14 August 2021, nine protesters gathered in Kirov to demand that upcoming parliamentary elections in Russia be free and fair.
On 5 August 2019, more than 300 people took part in an authorized protest in Novosibirsk against the hikes to energy tariffs.

Around 23 November 2021 (as reported), protesters gathered at a public area in Minusinsk to record a video appeal to the Russian president, demanding that he cancel mandatory coronavirus vaccination certificates for entry to a number of public spaces, including shopping malls, restaurants and government buildings, claiming the measures violated their rights, 'dehumanized' them and were a 'crime against humanity'.

On 16 February 2019, several dozen people took part in a protest in Nizhny Novgorod in opposition to the construction of a new temple in the local park, calling for the administration to develop it into a recreational zone instead. No incidents were reported.

On 5 August 2020, an unspecified number of people took part in a series of coordinated one-person protests in Vladikavkaz in support of the arrested organizer of protests denying the existence of the coronavirus pandemic and against the coronavirus containment measures that took place in Vladikavkaz in April.

On 23 February 2021, over 60 people set up a camp near Urdoma, alleging that the authorities are attempting to resume the construction of the massive waste collection polygon near the Shiyes station nearby.
On 22 December 2019, about 6-8 people took part in a protest in Yekaterinburg against the importation and storage of nuclear waste from Germany in the region.

On 25 July 2020, at least 3 people took part in a series of coordinated one-person protests in St. Petersburg-Tsentralny against Moscow's appointment of a new acting Khabarovsk Krai governor and in support of the previous LDPR governor of Khabarovsk Krai Sergei Furgal who was arrested on charges of involvement in multiple murders of several businessmen in the region and nearby territories in 2004 and 2005. His supporters maintain that the charges were politically motivated.

On 2 July 2020, at least 3 activists took part in a series of coordinated one-person protests in Syktyvkar against the set of constitutional amendments that could extend Vladimir Putin's presidential term past 2024.
On 3 December 2018, parents of children with disabilities protested in Kirov demanding an increase in their social benefits.

On 6 February 2021, about 100 people took part in a demonstration in support of the government of President Vladimir Putin in Arkhangelsk, which was filmed on posted on social following several large protests in support of opposition politician Alexei Navalny between January 23 and 31, 2021.

On 22 September 2019, at least 3 activists took part in coordinated one-person protests in Tambov against the so-called rubbish reform and the construction of new rubbish collection and recycling plants in Arkhangelsk oblast.

On 5 September 2020, about 100 people took part in a series of coordinated one-person protests in St. Petersburg-Tsentralny in support of Khabarovsk and Belarusian protesters, as well as in support of poisoned opposition figure Alexei Navalny.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Centre for Combating Extremism; Military Forces of Russia (2000-) National Guard
notes: On 14 October 2021, at least 20 allegedly pro-government protesters entered a screening room at the headquarters of Memorial, a renowned Russian NGO, in Moscow - Central, attempting to force organizers to cancel the screening of an anti-Soviet film. The protesters shouted slogans such as 'shame!', 'fascists!' and 'leave!'. Police, National Guard and the Center for Combating Extremism arrived and detained several of the protesters. Participants of the screening claimed police detained only 3 out of at least 20 protesters and expressed doubts as to whether those detained were taken to a police station. People present at the screening also claimed that police forced them to stay at the premises for an excessive amount of time, and that officers arbitrarily confiscated some of the facility's equipments, in an attempt to intimidate organizers from organizing events with messages that are not in line with the Russian government's vision of Soviet history.

On 9 December 2019, at least 10 activists took part in a series of coordinated one-person protests in Omsk in support of two Rostov-on-Don activists who were sentenced to over 6 years in prison for taking part in unauthorized protests.
On 19 May 2021, local residents staged a protest against the cutting down of trees in the Otradnoe park in Moscow, blocking the path of the construction vehicles.
On 17 December 2019, an unspecified number of people took part in a protest in the village of Ali-Yurt against the plans to set up a new aluminium plant in the region.

On 28 January 2018, protestors gathered in Sochi for a demonstration against what they believed to be a fraudulent building project. The organization that organized the protest, the 'Association of Deceived Shareholders', claimed that over 200 people participated in the rally.
On 17 September 2021, Belarusians living in Russia gathered at an unspecified location in Moscow in solidarity with political prisoners in Belarus.
On 25 February 2018, there was a rally in Kazan in order to commemorate the death of Boris Nemtsov. The exact number of participants is not known.
On 21 December 2019, an unspecified number of people took part in a protest in Saint Petersburg's Primorsky district against the expansion of construction projects into the city's green zones.

On 22 September 2020, about 300 people took part in a violent demonstration in the village of Krasnoarmeyskoye over to a land dispute with the local authorities, claiming ownership of several plots of land in the vicinity. The demonstrators threw rocks at the police, who responded with tear gas, tasers, and less-than-lethal munitions, detaining at least 27 people in the process. 2 people reported injuries that required medical assistance.
On 11 July 2020, at least 8 people took part in a protest in Vladikavkaz in support of a local resident who is being accused of financing terror groups.

On 29 June 2018, residents of Dagestan protested against the arrest of a fellow villager in Khasavyurt. Protesters blocked the road, which prevented the police officer from taking away the villager. They unblocked the road once the villager was released.

On 29 November 2019, about 15 people took part in a series of coordinated one person protests in central Moscow in front of the Prosecutor General's Office in support of a Komsomolsk activist who is accused of spreading pornography because of her sharing body-positive images on social media.

On 18 May 2018, following the murder of a woman, citizens of Psebay participated in a spontaneous rally in Psebay to protest against the result of the murder investigation, which they believe did not take into consideration all elements and aimed at protecting teenagers with family ties to local power structures. The head of Psebay district Pavel Zharkov resigned shortly after on 21 May 2018 and was replaced by Aleksey Bukin.

On 22 September 2019, about 60 people took part in an authorized ecological protest in Kirov against the so-called rubbish reform and the construction of new rubbish collection and recycling plants in Arkhangelsk oblast.
On 1 May 2018 the rally Monstratsia was held in Khabarovsk. The demonstration was mocking of official May 1 events.
On 14 November 2020, about 40 people staged a protest in St. Petersburg-Vyborgsky against the plans to demolish the building of the old research institute.

On 19 July 2020, people took part in a protest in Komsomolsk-on-Amur in support of the LDPR governor of Khabarovsk Krai Sergei Furgal who was arrested on charges of involvement in multiple murders of several businessmen in the region and nearby territories in 2004 and 2005. His supporters maintain that the charges were politically motivated.

On 5 February 2021, an unspecified number of people took part in a demonstration in support of the government of President Vladimir Putin in Khasavyurt, following several large protests in support of opposition politician Alexei Navalny between January 23 and 31, 2021.

On 11 October 2021, three protesters gathered in Serpukhov, Moscow Oblast, to demand limits be imposed on emissions by a local ceramics factory. Police intervened in the event, detaining all three participants, presumably for participating in an unauthorized protest.

On 12 December 2021, approximately 300 protesters gathered in Glazov to oppose the mandatory use of coronavirus vaccination certificates for entry to a number of public spaces, including shopping malls, restaurants and government buildings.
On 16 November 2019, about 90 people took part in an authorized protest in Rostov-on-Don against the construction of a new rubbish collection plant near a residential area in the city.
On 17 June 2020, several dozen local residents took part in a protest in the village of Sukhtelinskiy, demanding the authorities address the issues with inconsistent water supply in the region.

On 31 July 2021, protesters gathered in Khabarovsk to demand the release from prison of the former governor of Khabarovsk Oblast, Sergei Furgal, who was arrested in summer 2020 on charges of organizing murders in the early 2000s.
On 22 June 2020, over 100 activists took part in a protest in Omsk against the proposed set of constitutional amendments which could extend Vladimir Putin's presidential term past 2024.

On 19 February 2019, around 100 people took part in a protest in the town of Cheryomushki in opposition to the proposed plans to deconstruct the last remaining bridge over the Enisei river after the authorities failed to secure a maintenance contractor for the bridge. No incidents were reported.
On 2 January 2021, people took part in a protest in St. Petersburg-Vyborgsky in defence of a historic building that is planned to be demolished.
On 28 October 2018, residents of Novoaltaysk held a rally demanding gasification in their district and called on authorities to deal with other problems, such as bad roads and poor quality of water.
On 15 April 2021, local residents took part in a series of coordinated 'one-person protests' in Novorossiysk against the plans to close down a local kindergarten.
On 9 February 2022, protesters gathered at a forest near Troitsk in Moscow - Novomoskovsky to oppose plans to cut down 10 hectares of a nearby forest to build a school and a highway.
On 25 February 2018, the rally was held in Izhevsk to commemorate Boris Nemtsov. It was attended by around 20 people.

On 28 December 2021, protesters gathered in front of the city council in Anapa to oppose the new general plan for the city, claiming thousands of residential parcels could be confiscated and that the construction of homes would be banned in a large part of the city. With the support of police forces, Cossacks intervened in the event, beating a blogger activist and another participant of the event, in an attempt to have participants disperse.

On 13 January 2018, residents of Vladikavkaz municipality held a picke protest in support of the family of Vladimir Tskaev, who died in custody after police interrogation in 2015. His family claims that he was tortured and de facto killed by law enforcers. Several policemen are under investigation regarding this matter. Around 300 individuals attended.

On Sept. 2, 2018: Citizens from the city of Rostov-on-Don protested at the intersection of Dovator Street and Garnizon Lane against the construction of a garbage processing plant. Protesters said the plant would be located too close to residential buildings in the city.
On 6 December 2019, at least 4 activists took part in a series of coordinated one-person protests in Novosibirsk in support of Russia's political prisoners.

On 29 June 2019, at least 9 people took part in an authorized protest in Shadrinsk against the hazardous emissions from the local chemical plant, demanding a probe into its activities. No incidents were reported.

On 15 January 2022, three protesters gathered for coordinated 'one-person pickets' on Pushkin Square in Moscow - Central to demand free and fair elections, freedom of the press, the release of political prisoners and the dismissal of the Russian president. Another demonstrator at the nearby Red Square also stood in protest in support of political prisoners. Police intervened and detained all 4 participants of the event.

On 21 April 2019, an unspecified number of activists took part in a protest in Yekaterinburg in opposition to the plans to transfer the Khimmash house of culture to private ownership. No incidents were reported.

On 30 September 2019, about 100 people took part in an unauthorized protest in Beslan against the territorial elections administration decision to register several United Russia candidates with prior criminal convictions.

On 16 February 2022, protesters gathered in Krasnoyarsk in support the leader of the Republic of Chechnya (a region of Russia), denouncing the family of a former judge of the Chechen Supreme Court, whose son is suspected of editing a Telegram channel critical of Chechen authorities. Demonstrators also demanded the closing of several independent Russian media.
On 23 November 2019, about 60 people took part in an authorized protest in Syktyvkar calling upon the authorities to lift the restriction on holding protests at Syktyvkar's central square.

On 8 December 2019, 6 activists took part in a series of coordinated one-person protests in Volgograd calling for the release of an activist sentenced to a term in a colony-prison term for participation in the Moscow protests in the summer of 2019.

On 11 July 2020, between 10.000 and 35.000 people took part in an unauthorized protest in Khabarovsk in support of the LDPR governor of Khabarovsk Krai who was arrested on charges of involvement in multiple murders of several businessmen in the region and nearby territories in 2004 and 2005. His supporters maintain that the charges were politically motivated.

On 14 January 2022, several dozen protesters gathered in front of their homes in Makhachkala to demand from local authorities that they resolve the issue of regular power outages and water cuts in their neighborhood.

On Sunday, February 3, 2019, around 100 people took part in a protest calling for the resignation of the local mayor and members of his administration for alleged incompetence in the town of Ust-Ilimsk. No incidents were reported.
On 15 February 2019, at least 10 activists took part in a protest in defence of unrestricted internet in central Moscow. At least one activist was detained by police during the event.

On 25 July 2020, about 300 people took part in an unauthorized protest in Vladivostok against Moscow's appointment of a new acting Khabarovsk Krai governor and in support of the previous LDPR governor of Khabarovsk Krai Sergei Furgal who was arrested on charges of involvement in multiple murders of several businessmen in the region and nearby territories in 2004 and 2005. His supporters maintain that the charges were politically motivated. Police detained 4 protesters.
On 31 August 2021, three activists gathered in Moscow - Central to demand the release of political prisoners in Russia. Police intervened in the event and detained all participants.
On 24 July 2019, several dozen people took part in a protest in Sayanogorsk against the rubbish reforms and the plans to install rubbish collection bins in their neighborhood.

On 28 November 2021, approximately 50 local residents gathered at Krasny Most ('red bridge') in a park on the outskirts of Kursk to demand that a private company immediately cease demolition works on the bridge, claiming the construction was part of the region's cultural heritage.
On 25 August 2019, 3 activists were detained by police in Moscow while taking part in an unauthorized protest 'For Change of Power'.

On 29 December 2021, protesters gathered for coordinated 'one-person pickets' in Astrakhan to denounce the decision the day earlier by Russia's Supreme Court to disband Memorial, a renowned Russian NGO founded by Soviet dissidents in the late 1980s to research political repression by Soviet authorities.

On 1 July 2020, 5 activists took part in a series of coordinated one-person protests in Volgograd against the proposed set of constitutional amendments which could extend Vladimir Putin's presidential term past 2024.

On 7 January 2022, at least seven protesters gathered for coordinated 'one-person pickets' in front of a monument to a Kazakh poet on Chistoprudnyy Boulevard in Moscow - Central in support of mass protests in Kazakhstan, participants of which were demanding the withdrawal from politics of the influential former president Nursultan Nazarbayev. Police intervened to disperse the event, detaining all of its participants.
On 25 March 2020, about 15 people took part in a protest in Vladivostok against the proposed set of constitutional amendments that could extend Vladimir Putin's presidential term beyond 2024.

On 16 November 2020, about 150 people took part in an unauthorized protest in the Krivaya Balka settlement on the outskirts of Makhachkala, blocking the road and demanding the authorities address the issues with electric supply in the area. Police dispersed the protesters, allegedly spraying tear gas to do so. Police officials denied that any special equipment was used. No detentions or arrests were reported.
On 1 May 2019, about 10 activists took part in a so-called 'Monstration' protest in Vladivostok, a protest involving deliberately absurdist slogans as a way of criticizing the government.

On 09 October 2018, residents of temporary 'emergency' housing launched a two week protest against the forced eviction of their houses by the local authorities in Zelenodolsk. Local authorities have been evicting family residing in these emergency temporary accommodation without offering any relocation.
On 22 December 2019, at least a dozen people who lost their housing during the floods took part in a protest in Tulun, demanding the authorities step up their reconstruction and assistance efforts.
On 25 July 2019, about 50 cheated housing interest holders staged a protest in Kazan demanding that local authorities assist them with securing their housing.

On 26 February 2019, around 8 activists staged a protest on a road leading to the construction site of the new rubbish site being constructed near Urdoma as part of the federal rubbish reform. The protesters blocked construction vehicles from passing, claiming that both the construction of the rubbish site itself, and the road that was being used, were started illegally.

On 21 June 2021, approximately 100 protesters gathered in Barnaul to demand the completion of an apartment building project in which they bought property, which was allegedly being delayed by an investor close to the mayor of Barnaul.
On 9 March 2020, several dozen people took part in an authorized protest on the Brevennik island in Arkhangelsk against the plans to construct new waste incinerators in the region.

On 1 March 2021, about 200 residents of nearby towns and villages staged a protest in Makhachkala demanding the regional authorities address the issues with intermittent supply of heating gas in their area.

On 18 July 2020, about 20 people took part in a series of protests in Volgograd against the new set of constitutional amendments passed earlier in July that could extend Vladimit Putin's presidential term limits beyond 2024. The activists were taking part in protests and soliciting signatures from passers-by calling for the roll-back of the amendments.

On 22 September 2019, at least 4 activists took part in an authorized ecological protest in Yaroslavl against the so-called rubbish reform and the construction of new rubbish collection and recycling plants in Arkhangelsk oblast.

On 22 February 2020, at least 4 activists took part in a series of coordinated one person protests in Astrakhan in support of Russia's political prisoners, including those charged in the Set (Network) case.

On 22 May 2019, 15 cheated housing interest holders took part in an authorized protest in Novosibirsk calling upon the authorities to assist them in securing the completion of their housing's construction. No incidents were reported.
On Sunday, February 3, 2019, around 40 people took part in a protest in Kaliningrad in opposition to the rubbish collection reform. No incidents were reported.

On 11 September 2021, police detained four protesters who gathered at Pushkin Square in Moscow - Central to demand the repeal of the Russian law on foreign agents and to denounce a recent decision, by which Russia's largest independent television channel, TV Rain, was declared a 'foreign agent'.
On 22 May 2021, 13 local residents staged a protest against the installation of new cellular tower in Krasny Sulin, stating that it is too close to their housing.

On 1 September 2019, 4 activists took part in coordinated one-person protests in Volgograd criticizing the policies of the United Russia government and in support of free and fair access to local elections.

On 28 October 2018, a rally was held in Belgorod, the participants of which condemned the authorities' intention to stop urban and suburban trolley bus routes and suspected them of supporting the bus company 'Belkomtrans.'

On 30 October 2020, 7 activists staged a series of one-person protests in Krasnodar to commemorate the Day of Remembrance of the Victims of Political Repressions and demand more financial aid to the families of the repressed individuals.

On 24 February 2019, around 100 people took part in an authorized protest in Voronezh commemorating the anniversary of Boris Nemtsov's murder and calling upon the authorities to find the organizers. No incidents were reported.
On 12 January 2020, about a dozen activists took part in a protest in Voronezh in support of the Taygan safari-park in Crimea.
On 12 March 2018, activists from the '14%' movement organized a demonstration in Moscow's triumphal square. Members were later detained by police.
On 12 February 2022, activists gathered in front of Botanicheskaya metro station in Yekaterinburg to protest against a possible war by Russia against Ukraine.

On 12 February 2019, several dozen people took part in a spontaneous protest in Gus-Khrustalny in opposition to the local authorities' decision to limit the distribution of subsidized wood for heating and construction purposes. No incidents were reported.

On 3 March 2022, protesters gathered at various locations in Kazan to oppose the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 20 of its participants.
On 18 March 2022, 2,500 people gathered in Penza to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.
On 30 January 2023, around 400 residents gathered in Petrozavodsk to take part in a concert-rally in support of the Russian military invasion of Ukraine.
On 1 April 2022, almost 250 residents gathered in Ulyanovsk to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine.
On 13 March 2022, protesters gathered in Murom to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 1 participant.

On 26 November 2022, residents protested in Ryazan against the restrictions imposed on several neighborhoods in the Ryazan region, which are related to their current status of cultural heritage ('Yesenin's Russia').
On 7 April 2022, several hundred of people gathered in Nefteyugansk to show support for the Russian armed forces that are taking part in the Russian military invasion in Ukraine.

On 18 September 2022, around 250 protesters staged a demonstration in Perm against the rise in public transportation tariffs. The organizers had previously obtained a permission to hold the event from the authorities.

On 17 April 2022, 150 residents gathered in Tomsk, protesting against the construction of a new residential area. Activists said that the new microdistrict would overload the transport infrastructure.

On 2 March 2022, protesters gathered in Vladimir to oppose the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 3 of its participants.
On 1 July 2022, protesters gathered in Chita, protesting against the increase in public utility tariffs from the beginning of July 2022.
On 4 April 2022, around 250 people gathered in Pskov to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine.

On 27 February 2022, protesters gathered in Krasnoyarsk to oppose the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 3 of its participants.
On 24 February 2022, protesters gathered in Smolensk to oppose a large-scale invasion of Ukraine by Russia, which had begun in the early hours of the day.

On 27 February 2022, protesters gathered at various locations in Irkutsk to oppose the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 18 of its participants.

On 25 February 2022, protesters gathered in Perm to oppose a large-scale invasion of Ukraine by Russia, which had begun in the early hours the day before. Police intervened in the demonstrations, detaining at least 5 participants.
On 20 February 2023, activists staged pickets in front of the regional parliament building in Novosibirsk, protesting against the abolition of direct mayoral elections.

On 27 February 2022, protesters gathered in Vologda to oppose the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 3 of its participants.
On 5 March 2023, residents protested in Volchikha, demanding that the authorities provide a local hospital with the necessary equipment and solve the problem of staff shortage.
On 29 September 2022, around 40 protesters staged a demonstration in Kostroma, demanding the city administration to resolve the problems with heating and hot water.

On 13 March 2022, protesters gathered in Samara to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 2 of its participants.
On 2 April 2022, people gathered in Oryol to support the Russian military invasion Ukraine.

On 27 February 2022, protesters gathered at various locations in Kazan to oppose the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 46 of its participants.

On 26 February 2022, protesters gathered in Irkutsk to oppose the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 5 of its participants.
On 18 March 2022, 12,000 people gathered in Lipetsk to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.

On 2 May 2022, 3 protesters in St. Petersburg participated in a series of pickets at different locations, protesting against the Russian military invasion in Ukraine. Police intervened in the event, arresting all protesters.
On 8 April 2022, people gathered in Kazan to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine.
On 29 April 2023, over 300 people protested in Chelyabinsk against the bill authorizing the euthanasia of stray dogs.
On 18 December 2022, around 20 residents gathered in St. Petersburg, protesting against the cutting down of a local green area.

Around 14 November 2022 (as reported), dozens of residents gathered in Novyi Khushet, demanding the authorities put an end to the illegal land seizure and find a solution to the problem with the allocation of land to the residents. People complained that they have waited for years for the land slots to be allocated to them by the local authorities.

On 6 March 2022, protesters gathered in Krasnoyarsk to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 64 of its participants.
On 13 May 2022, over 200 residents in Surgut participated in a demonstration in support of the Russian military forces in Ukraine and the independence of the Ukrainian breakaway regions in Donbas.

On 8 October 2023, people protested in Novosibirsk (Novosibirsk) against the deforestation of the town for new construction projects as it harms the environment. The protesters demanded that the city halt the construction of a new university campus on a green territory filled with rare plants and trees.
On 22 April 2023, around 100 people protested in Iskitim against the construction of carceral facilities close to residential houses.
On 18 March 2022, people gathered in Chelyabinsk to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.

On 6 March 2022, protesters gathered in Arkhangelsk to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 4 of its participants.

On 26 August 2023, residents blocked the road in Makhachkala, protesting over utility cuts and demanding that the electricity supply be restored. One of the villages near Makhachkala has been cut off from electricity for several days now.
On 18 March 2022, 6,000 people gathered in Astrakhan to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.

On 24 July 2022, over 10 activists staged a series of organized pickets in Novosibirsk, protesting against cutting down forests to clear space for new buildings in the neighborhood of Akademgorodok. They plan to continue the protest action for 6 days.
On 13 August 2023, activists staged pickets in Dyadkovo against the reconstruction of a local road.
On 24 August 2022, 4 protesters staged anti-war protest actions at different locations in Moscow, due to the Russian military invasion of Ukraine. Police arrested all protesters.

Around 29 October 2023 (as reported), an unidentified group of four men attacked a man on Prud-Klyuchiki street in Moscow - South-Eastern (Yugo-Vostochnyy, Moscow) because he looked like someone 'from the Caucasus.' They sprayed pepper spray onto him and shot twice from a flare gun into his face.
On 2 June 2023, activists staged a protest action in the Bitsevsky Forest in Moscow, trying to stop construction works there. Police arrested 3 protesters.

On 6 March 2022, approximately 300 protesters gathered in Yekaterinburg to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 137 of its participants.

On 2 March 2022, protesters gathered at various locations in Chelyabinsk to oppose the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 16 of its participants.

On 24 February 2022, protesters gathered in Ulan-Ude to oppose a large-scale invasion of Ukraine by Russia, which had begun in the early hours of the day. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least one participant, who was broadcasting the event online.

On 24 February 2022, protesters gathered in Tyumen to oppose a large-scale invasion of Ukraine by Russia, which had begun in the early hours of the day. Police intervened in the demonstration, detaining approximately 30 participants.

On 8 March 2022, protesters gathered in Tomsk to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 7 of its participants.

On 14 October 2023, activists protested in St. Petersburg - Admiralteysky (Admiralteyskiy, Saint Petersburg) against the demolition of Ustinov house - an early 20th century building that is supposed to be protected from demolition according to law, but is being destroyed to make way for a multi-story apartment building on the street.
On 10 July 2023, people protested in Ulyanovsk against the opening of a correctional facility in their neighborhood.

On 24 February 2022, protesters gathered in Vladimir to oppose a large-scale invasion of Ukraine by Russia, which had begun in the early hours of the day. Police intervened in the demonstration, detaining at least 4 of its participants.

On 18 March 2022, people gathered in Vladimir to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.

On 7 September 2023, more than 50 people gathered near Sarykum hotel to protest against construction of a landfill between the Sarykum dune and the village of Novaya Urada. Police detained 8 activists from the protest who were then taken to the Kumtorkalinskiy district police department.

On 24 February 2022, protesters gathered in Izhevsk to oppose a large-scale invasion of Ukraine by Russia, which had begun in the early hours of the day. Police intervened in the demonstrations, detaining at least 12 participants.

On 6 March 2022, protesters gathered in Miass to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 4 of its participants.

On 28 August 2023, residents of the Obolensk in the Moscow Region gathered and demanded from the Governor of their district to return bus routes to Moscow that were reduced from four times an day to two times a day.

On 27 February 2022, approximately 15 protesters gathered in Kirov to commemorate the 7th anniversary of the murder of the renowned Russian dissident and opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, and to demand the prosecution of the organizers of his killing.
On 7 April 2022, over 300 people gathered in Syktyvkar to show support for the Russian armed forces that are taking part in the Russian military invasion in Ukraine.

On 13 May 2023, parents protested in one of the districts in Vladivostok, demanding the authorities restore former school facilities and open them for new students. Protesters complained about the lack of places in local schools.
On 7 April 2022, over 600 people gathered in Belogorsk to show support for the Russian armed forces taking part in the Russian military invasion in Ukraine.
On 22 July 2023, around 15 people protested in Khabarovsk in support of the jailed former governor of the region.
On 7 April 2022, 500 people gathered in Salekhard to show support for the independence of the Moscow-backed separatist Donbass regions and for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine.
On 18 March 2022, 5 thousand people gathered in Tver to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.

On 4 March 2022, protesters gathered at various locations in Moscow to oppose the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 46 of its participants.
On 7 April 2022, 350 people gathered in Ulyanovsk to show support for the independence of the Moscow-backed separatist Donbass regions and for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine.
Around 8 August 2022 (as reported), residents in villages near Bogolyubovo protested against the construction of a highway through one of the villages.
On 18 March 2022, residents of Sochi participated in a motor rally to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.
On 18 March 2022, people gathered in Kurgan to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.
On 13 May 2023, people staged pickets in Lozy against the construction of a landfill close to their homes.
On 10 March 2023, residents protested in Novaya Urada against the construction of a landfill close to their homes.
On 13 March 2022, protesters gathered in Kazan to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 20 participant.
On 3 April 2023, around a dozen people protested in the Abinskiy district against the planned construction of a landfill in the area, due to environmental concerns. (coded to Abinsk)
On 25 May 2022, residents gathered in St. Petersburg, protesting against the construction of alluvial territories in the northern part of Vasilyevsky Island.

On 16 September 2023, around 30 people protested in Kremenkul (Sosnovskiy, Chelyabinsk) against a vegetable market in their village. They believe that the migrants working at the market are breaking the law.
On 13 November 2022, people gathered in Tambov to participate in a rally in support of the Russian military invasion of Ukraine.
On 13 June 2022, around 40-50 residents gathered in a park in Yekaterinburg, protesting against the ongoing road construction.
On 23 July 2023, residents protested in Ulan-Ude against the construction of a penitentiary center in their neighborhood.
On 16 September 2023, a group of men protested next to the Armenian Union building in Tyumen (Tyumen). They wore face coverings and chanted anti-migration xenophobic slogans and slurs.
On 18 March 2022, people gathered in Yoshkar-Ola to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.

On 18 March 2022, residents of Vologda participated in a motor rally in Vologda to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.

On 8 March 2022, protesters gathered in Vladivostok to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 8 of its participants.
On 18 March 2022, people gathered in Barnaul (Altai) to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.

On 12 November 2023, people protested in a park in Kupchino district in St. Petersburg - Frunzensky (Frunzenskiy, Saint Petersburg) against the demolition of the park to make way for an apartment building.

On 6 March 2022, protesters gathered in Ufa to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 46 of its participants.

On 6 March 2022, protesters gathered in Taganrog to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 4 of its participants.

On 26 February 2022, protesters gathered in Yekaterinburg to support the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February, claiming that the war would bring security to the people of the Ukrainian region of Donbass.

On 23 March 2023, over 20 residents blocked a road in Poltavskaya, preventing heavy trucks from transporting garbage to a landfill. The landfill has sparked protests among residents over numerous health and safety violations, as well as environmental concerns.

On 26 February 2022, protesters gathered in Chelyabinsk to oppose the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 5 of its participants.

On 24 February 2022, protesters gathered in Tomsk to oppose a large-scale invasion of Ukraine by Russia, which had begun in the early hours of the day. Police intervened in the demonstration, detaining at least 3 of its participants.
On 29 October 2023, people protested in Makhachkala (Republic of Dagestan) in support of Palestine. Several protesters were detained by the police.

On 3 March 2022, protesters gathered at various locations in Yekaterinburg to oppose the large-scale invasion and war against Ukraine by Russia, which began on 24 February. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 12 of its participants.

On 6 March 2022, protesters gathered in Irkutsk to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 50 of its participants.
On 18 March 2022, people gathered in Kirov to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.
On 18 April 2022, residents gathered in Chita in support of the Russian military invasion in Ukraine.

On 6 March 2022, protesters gathered in Belgorod to oppose the large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, which started on February 24. Police intervened in the event, detaining at least 7 of its participants.
On 18 March 2022, people gathered in Vladivostok to show support for the Russian military invasion in Ukraine and to celebrate the anniversary of the annexation of Crimea by Russia.

On 6 April 2023, police dispersed the protesters in Poltavskaya, who had been blocking the road for two days to prevent trucks from transporting garbage to a nearby landfill through a neighborhood in which people live.
On 30 October 2023, around 50 people protested in Novosibirsk (Novosibirsk) in support of current Russian political prisoners and to commemorate the victims of Soviet repressions.
